Jerry_Jaye:
{{short description|American country/rockabilly singer (born 1937)}}
'''Jerry Jaye''' (born October 19, 1937 in [[Manila, Arkansas]]) is an American [[country music|country]]/[[rockabilly]] singer.

Jaye grew up on a [[sharecropper]]'s farm and did a stint in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] from 1954 to 1958. After his return he started a band with bassist Tommy Baker and drummer Carl Frye, who began playing the local [[Arkansas]] circuits. In 1966, the group traveled to [[Memphis, Tennessee]], and recorded a single, "[[My Girl Josephine]]" (a hit for [[Fats Domino]] the previous decade). The single was initially released in a press run of 500; Jaye shopped the disc to local radio stations, and as the tune began getting airplay, Jaye signed a contract with [[Hi Records]] for national distribution.<ref name=rbhof>[http://www.rockabillyhall.com/JerryJaye1.html Jerry Jaye] at the Rockabilly Hall of Fame. Accessed October 16, 2007</ref> Re-released in 1967, "My Girl Josephine" became a [[hit single]] in the US, peaking at No. 29 on the [[Billboard magazine|Billboard]] Pop Singles chart.<ref name=amg1>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p39632/charts-awards/billboard-singles|pure_url=yes}} Billboard Singles], Allmusic.com</ref> A full-length LP, ''My Girl Josephine'', followed, which hit No. 195 in the US,<ref>[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p39632/charts-awards|pure_url=yes}} Billboard], Allmusic.com</ref> but four further singles from the album failed to make an impact on the charts. During this time Jaye toured with [[Booker T and the MGs]] and [[Lou Rawls]] among others.

Jaye left Hi Records in 1970 and began recording new material for [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]'s Mega/Raintree. Seven singles were released, some of which found regional success.<ref name=rbhof/> Between 1974 and 1975 he sang lead with the [[Bill Black Combo]] after its founder's death. In 1975, Jaye signed with [[Columbia Records]], first releasing a [[cover version|cover]] of [[Tommy Edwards]]'s "[[It's All in the Game (song)|It's All in the Game]]". This was followed by two further US Country hits (again with Hi Records) in 1976, "Honky Tonk Women Love Redneck Men" (US Country No. 32) and "Hot and Still Heatin' (US Country No. 78).<ref name=amg1/> In 1979 he left Hi again, and began touring the [[American South]] with his wife Darlene Battles. Together they released an album on [[Bejay Records]][http://www.slipcue.com/music/country/countrystyles/regional/states-arkansas_01.html] in 1984. Jaye toured [[Sweden]] and [[England]] in the 1990s, and released another album, ''One More Time'', in 2005.
